135 /*
136  There are 8 different type of table access so there is no more than
137  combinations 2^8 = 256:
138 
139  . STMT_READS_TRANS_TABLE
140 
141  . STMT_READS_NON_TRANS_TABLE
142 
143  . STMT_READS_TEMP_TRANS_TABLE
144 
145  . STMT_READS_TEMP_NON_TRANS_TABLE
146 
147  . STMT_WRITES_TRANS_TABLE
148 
149  . STMT_WRITES_NON_TRANS_TABLE
150 
151  . STMT_WRITES_TEMP_TRANS_TABLE
152 
153  . STMT_WRITES_TEMP_NON_TRANS_TABLE
154 
155  The unsafe conditions for each combination is represented within a byte
156  and stores the status of the option --binlog-direct-non-trans-updates,
157  whether the trx-cache is empty or not, and whether the isolation level
158  is lower than ISO_REPEATABLE_READ:
159 
160  . option (OFF/ON)
161  . trx-cache (empty/not empty)
162  . isolation (>= ISO_REPEATABLE_READ / < ISO_REPEATABLE_READ)
163 
164  bits 0 : . OFF, . empty, . >= ISO_REPEATABLE_READ
165  bits 1 : . OFF, . empty, . < ISO_REPEATABLE_READ
166  bits 2 : . OFF, . not empty, . >= ISO_REPEATABLE_READ
167  bits 3 : . OFF, . not empty, . < ISO_REPEATABLE_READ
168  bits 4 : . ON, . empty, . >= ISO_REPEATABLE_READ
169  bits 5 : . ON, . empty, . < ISO_REPEATABLE_READ
170  bits 6 : . ON, . not empty, . >= ISO_REPEATABLE_READ
171  bits 7 : . ON, . not empty, . < ISO_REPEATABLE_READ
172 */
173 extern uint binlog_unsafe_map[256];
174 /*
175  Initializes the array with unsafe combinations and its respective
176  conditions.
177 */
178 void binlog_unsafe_map_init();
179 
180 /*
181  If we encounter a diagnostics statement (GET DIAGNOSTICS, or e.g.
182  the old SHOW WARNINGS|ERRORS, or "diagnostics variables" such as
183  @@warning_count | @@error_count, we'll set some hints so this
184  information is not lost. DA_KEEP_UNSPECIFIED is used in LEX constructor to
185  avoid leaving variables uninitialized.
186  */
187 enum enum_keep_diagnostics {
188  DA_KEEP_NOTHING = 0, /**< keep nothing */
189  DA_KEEP_DIAGNOSTICS, /**< keep the diagnostics area */
190  DA_KEEP_COUNTS, /**< keep \@warning_count / \@error_count */
191  DA_KEEP_PARSE_ERROR, /**< keep diagnostics area after parse error */
192  DA_KEEP_UNSPECIFIED /**< keep semantics is unspecified */
193 };

209 /**
210  enum_sp_type defines type codes of stored programs.
211 
212  @note these codes are used when dealing with the mysql.routines system table,
213  so they must not be changed.
214 
215  @note the following macros were used previously for the same purpose. Now they
216  are used for ACL only.
217 */
218 enum class enum_sp_type {
219  FUNCTION = 1,
220  PROCEDURE,
221  TRIGGER,
222  EVENT,
223  /*
224  Must always be the last one.
225  Denotes an error condition.
226  */
227  INVALID_SP_TYPE
228 };
229 
230 inline enum_sp_type to_sp_type(longlong val) {
231  if (val >= static_cast<longlong>(enum_sp_type::FUNCTION) &&
232  val < static_cast<longlong>(enum_sp_type::INVALID_SP_TYPE))
233  return static_cast<enum_sp_type>(val);
234  else
235  return enum_sp_type::INVALID_SP_TYPE;
236 }
237 
238 inline longlong to_longlong(enum_sp_type val) {
239  return static_cast<longlong>(val);
240 }
241 
242 inline uint to_uint(enum_sp_type val) { return static_cast<uint>(val); }
243 
244 /*
245  Values for the type enum. This reflects the order of the enum declaration
246  in the CREATE TABLE command. These values are used to enumerate object types
247  for the ACL statements.
248 
249  These values were also used for enumerating stored program types. However, now
250  enum_sp_type should be used for that instead of them.
251 */
252 #define TYPE_ENUM_FUNCTION 1
253 #define TYPE_ENUM_PROCEDURE 2
254 #define TYPE_ENUM_TRIGGER 3
255 #define TYPE_ENUM_PROXY 4

290 class Table_ident {
291  public:
292  LEX_CSTRING db;
293  LEX_CSTRING table;
294  SELECT_LEX_UNIT *sel;
295  Table_function *table_function;
296 
297  Table_ident(Protocol *protocol, const LEX_CSTRING &db_arg,
298  const LEX_CSTRING &table_arg, bool force);
299  Table_ident(const LEX_CSTRING &db_arg, const LEX_CSTRING &table_arg)
300  : db(db_arg), table(table_arg), sel(nullptr), table_function(nullptr) {}
301  Table_ident(const LEX_CSTRING &table_arg)
302  : table(table_arg), sel(nullptr), table_function(nullptr) {
303  db = NULL_CSTR;
304  }
305  /**
306  This constructor is used only for the case when we create a derived
307  table. A derived table has no name and doesn't belong to any database.
308  Later, if there was an alias specified for the table, it will be set
309  by add_table_to_list.
310  */
311  Table_ident(SELECT_LEX_UNIT *s) : sel(s), table_function(nullptr) {
312  db = EMPTY_CSTR; /* a subject to casedn_str */
313  table = EMPTY_CSTR;
314  }
315  /*
316  This constructor is used only for the case when we create a table function.
317  It has no name and doesn't belong to any database as it exists only
318  during query execution. Later, if there was an alias specified for the
319  table, it will be set by add_table_to_list.
320  */
321  Table_ident(LEX_CSTRING &table_arg, Table_function *table_func_arg)
322  : table(table_arg), sel(nullptr), table_function(table_func_arg) {
323  /* We must have a table name here as this is used with add_table_to_list */
324  db = EMPTY_CSTR; /* a subject to casedn_str */
325  }
326  // True if we can tell from syntax that this is a table function.
327  bool is_table_function() const { return (table_function != nullptr); }
328  // True if we can tell from syntax that this is an unnamed derived table.
329  bool is_derived_table() const { return sel; }
330  void change_db(const char *db_name) {
331  db.str = db_name;
332  db.length = strlen(db_name);
333  }
334 };

457 /*
458  String names used to print a statement with index hints.
459  Keep in sync with index_hint_type.
460 */
461 extern const char *index_hint_type_name[];
462 typedef uchar index_clause_map;
463 
464 /*
465  Bits in index_clause_map : one for each possible FOR clause in
466  USE/FORCE/IGNORE INDEX index hint specification
467 */
468 #define INDEX_HINT_MASK_JOIN (1)
469 #define INDEX_HINT_MASK_GROUP (1 << 1)
470 #define INDEX_HINT_MASK_ORDER (1 << 2)
471 
472 #define INDEX_HINT_MASK_ALL \
473  (INDEX_HINT_MASK_JOIN | INDEX_HINT_MASK_GROUP | INDEX_HINT_MASK_ORDER)
474 
475 /* Single element of an USE/FORCE/IGNORE INDEX list specified as a SQL hint */
476 class Index_hint {
477  public:
478  /* The type of the hint : USE/FORCE/IGNORE */
479  enum index_hint_type type;
480  /* Where the hit applies to. A bitmask of INDEX_HINT_MASK_<place> values */
481  index_clause_map clause;
482  /*
483  The index name. Empty (str=NULL) name represents an empty list
484  USE INDEX () clause
485  */
486  LEX_CSTRING key_name;
487 
488  Index_hint(const char *str, uint length) {
489  key_name.str = str;
490  key_name.length = length;
491  }
492 
493  void print(const THD *thd, String *str);
494 };

496 /*
497  Class SELECT_LEX_UNIT represents a query expression.
498  Class SELECT_LEX represents a query block.
499  A query expression contains one or more query blocks (more than one means
500  that we have a UNION query).
501  These classes are connected as follows:
502  Both classes have a master, a slave, a next and a prev field.
503  For class SELECT_LEX, master and slave connect to objects of type
504  SELECT_LEX_UNIT, whereas for class SELECT_LEX_UNIT, they connect
505  to SELECT_LEX.
506  master is pointer to outer node.
507  slave is pointer to the first inner node
508 
509  neighbors are two SELECT_LEX or SELECT_LEX_UNIT objects on
510  the same level.
511 
512  The structures are linked with the following pointers:
513  - list of neighbors (next/prev) (prev of first element point to slave
514  pointer of outer structure)
515  - For SELECT_LEX, this is a list of query blocks.
516  - For SELECT_LEX_UNIT, this is a list of subqueries.
517 
518  - pointer to outer node (master), which is
519  If this is SELECT_LEX_UNIT
520  - pointer to outer select_lex.
521  If this is SELECT_LEX
522  - pointer to outer SELECT_LEX_UNIT.
523 
524  - pointer to inner objects (slave), which is either:
525  If this is an SELECT_LEX_UNIT:
526  - first query block that belong to this query expression.
527  If this is an SELECT_LEX
528  - first query expression that belong to this query block (subqueries).
529 
530  - list of all SELECT_LEX objects (link_next/link_prev)
531  This is to be used for things like derived tables creation, where we
532  go through this list and create the derived tables.
533 
534  If query expression contain several query blocks (UNION now,
535  INTERSECT etc later) then it has a special select_lex called
536  fake_select_lex. It used for storing global parameters (like ORDER BY,
537  LIMIT) and executing union.
538  Subqueries used in global ORDER BY clause will be attached to this
539  fake_select_lex, which will allow them to correctly resolve fields of
540  the containing UNION and outer selects.
541 
542  For example for following query:
543 
544  select *
545  from table1
546  where table1.field IN (select * from table1_1_1 union
547  select * from table1_1_2)
548  union
549  select *
550  from table2
551  where table2.field=(select (select f1 from table2_1_1_1_1
552  where table2_1_1_1_1.f2=table2_1_1.f3)
553  from table2_1_1
554  where table2_1_1.f1=table2.f2)
555  union
556  select * from table3;
557 
558  we will have following structure:
559 
560  select1: (select * from table1 ...)
561  select2: (select * from table2 ...)
562  select3: (select * from table3)
563  select1.1.1: (select * from table1_1_1)
564  ...
565 
566  main unit
567  fake0
568  select1 select2 select3
569  |^^ |^
570  s||| ||master
571  l||| |+---------------------------------+
572  a||| +---------------------------------+|
573  v|||master slave ||
574  e||+-------------------------+ ||
575  V| neighbor | V|
576  unit1.1<+==================>unit1.2 unit2.1
577  fake1.1
578  select1.1.1 select 1.1.2 select1.2.1 select2.1.1
579  |^
580  ||
581  V|
582  unit2.1.1.1
583  select2.1.1.1.1
584 
585 
586  relation in main unit will be following:
587  (bigger picture for:
588  main unit
589  fake0
590  select1 select2 select3
591  in the above picture)
592 
593  main unit
594  |^^^^|fake_select_lex
595  |||||+--------------------------------------------+
596  ||||+--------------------------------------------+|
597  |||+------------------------------+ ||
598  ||+--------------+ | ||
599  slave||master | | ||
600  V| neighbor | neighbor | master|V
601  select1<========>select2<========>select3 fake0
602 
603  list of all select_lex will be following (as it will be constructed by
604  parser):
605 
606  select1->select2->select3->select2.1.1->select 2.1.2->select2.1.1.1.1-+
607  |
608  +---------------------------------------------------------------------+
609  |
610  +->select1.1.1->select1.1.2
611 
612 */
613 
614 /**
615  This class represents a query expression (one query block or
616  several query blocks combined with UNION).
617 */
618 class SELECT_LEX_UNIT {
619  /**
620  Intrusive double-linked list of all query expressions
621  immediately contained within the same query block.
622  */
623  SELECT_LEX_UNIT *next;
624  SELECT_LEX_UNIT **prev;
625 
626  /**
627  The query block wherein this query expression is contained,
628  NULL if the query block is the outer-most one.
629  */
630  SELECT_LEX *master;
631  /// The first query block in this query expression.
632  SELECT_LEX *slave;
633 
634  private:
635  /**
636  Marker for subqueries in WHERE, HAVING, ORDER BY, GROUP BY and
637  SELECT item lists.
638  Must be read/written when holding LOCK_query_plan.
639 
640  See Item_subselect::explain_subquery_checker
641  */
642  enum_parsing_context explain_marker;
643 
644  bool prepared; ///< All query blocks in query expression are prepared
645  bool optimized; ///< All query blocks in query expression are optimized
646  bool executed; ///< Query expression has been executed
647 
648  TABLE_LIST result_table_list{};
649  Query_result_union *union_result;

732  public:
733  /**
734  Pointer to query block containing global parameters for query.
735  Global parameters may include ORDER BY, LIMIT and OFFSET.
736 
737  If this is a union of multiple query blocks, the global parameters are
738  stored in fake_select_lex. If the union doesn't use a temporary table,
739  SELECT_LEX_UNIT::prepare() nulls out fake_select_lex, but saves a copy
740  in saved_fake_select_lex in order to preserve the global parameters.
741 
742  If this is not a union, and the query expression has no multi-level
743  ORDER BY/LIMIT, global parameters are in the single query block.
744 
745  @return query block containing the global parameters
746  */
747  inline SELECT_LEX *global_parameters() const {
748  if (fake_select_lex != nullptr)
749  return fake_select_lex;
750  else if (saved_fake_select_lex != nullptr)
751  return saved_fake_select_lex;
752  return first_select();
753  }
754  /* LIMIT clause runtime counters */
755  ha_rows select_limit_cnt, offset_limit_cnt;
756  /// Points to subquery if this query expression is used in one, otherwise NULL
757  Item_subselect *item;
758  /**
759  Helper query block for query expression with UNION or multi-level
760  ORDER BY/LIMIT
761  */
762  SELECT_LEX *fake_select_lex;
763  /**
764  SELECT_LEX that stores LIMIT and OFFSET for UNION ALL when no
765  fake_select_lex is used.
766  */
767  SELECT_LEX *saved_fake_select_lex;
768  /**
769  Points to last query block which has UNION DISTINCT on its left.
770  In a list of UNIONed blocks, UNION is left-associative; so UNION DISTINCT
771  eliminates duplicates in all blocks up to the first one on its right
772  included. Which is why we only need to remember that query block.
773  */
774  SELECT_LEX *union_distinct;
775 
776  /**
777  The WITH clause which is the first part of this query expression. NULL if
778  none.
779  */

783  table. NULL if none.
784  */

786  /**
787  First query block (in this UNION) which references the CTE.
788  NULL if not the query expression of a recursive CTE.
789  */
790  SELECT_LEX *first_recursive;
791 
792  /**
793  If 'this' is body of lateral derived table:
794  map of tables in the same FROM clause as this derived table, and to which
795  the derived table's body makes references.
796  In pre-resolution stages, this is OUTER_REF_TABLE_BIT, just to indicate
797  that this has LATERAL; after resolution, which has found references in the
798  body, this is the proper map (with no PSEUDO_TABLE_BITS anymore).
799  */
800  table_map m_lateral_deps;
801  /**
802  True if the with-recursive algorithm has produced the complete result.
803  In a recursive CTE, a JOIN is executed several times in a loop, and
804  should not be cleaned up (e.g. by join_free()) before all iterations of
805  the loop are done (i.e. before the CTE's result is complete).
806  */
807  bool got_all_recursive_rows;

845  /**
846  Ensures that there are iterators created for the access paths created
847  by optimize(), even if it was called with create_access_paths = false.
848  If there are already iterators, it is a no-op. optimize() must have
849  been called earlier.
850 
851  The use case for this is if we have a query block that's not top-level,
852  but we figure out after the fact that we wanted to run it anyway.
853  The typical case would be that we notice that the query block can return
854  at most one row (a so-called const table), and want to run it during
855  optimization.
856  */

878  the iterator executor or not) that is not available before optimize time.

889  /**
890  If and only if materialize_destination is non-nullptr, it means that the
891  caller intends to materialize our result into the given table. If it is
892  advantageous (in particular, if this query expression is a UNION DISTINCT),
893  optimize() will not create an iterator by itself, but rather do an
894  unfinished materialize. This means that it will collect iterators for
895  all the query blocks and prepare them for materializing into the given
896  table, but not actually create a root iterator for this query expression;
897  the caller is responsible for calling release_query_blocks_to_materialize()
898  and creating the iterator itself.
899 
900  Even if materialize_destination is non-nullptr, this function may choose
901  to make a regular iterator. The caller is responsible for checking
902  unfinished_materialization() if it has given a non-nullptr table.
903 
904  @param thd Thread handle.
905 
906  @param materialize_destination What table to try to materialize into,
907  or nullptr if the caller does not intend to materialize the result.
908 
909  @param create_iterators If false, only access paths are created,
910  not iterators. Only top level query blocks (these that we are to call
911  exec() on) should have iterators. See also force_create_iterators().
912  */
913  bool optimize(THD *thd, TABLE *materialize_destination,
914  bool create_iterators);

1004  // If we are doing a query with global LIMIT but without fake_select_lex,
1005  // we need somewhere to store the record count for FOUND_ROWS().
1006  // It can't be in any of the JOINs, since they may have their own
1007  // LimitOffsetIterators, which will write to join->send_records
1008  // whenever there is an OFFSET. (It also can't be in saved_fake_select_lex,
1009  // which has no join.) Thus, we'll keep it here instead.
1010  //
1011  // If we have a fake_select_lex, we use its send_records instead
1012  // (since its LimitOffsetIterator will write there), and if we don't
1013  // have a UNION, FOUND_ROWS() refers to the (single) JOIN, and thus,
1014  // we use its send_records.
1015  ha_rows send_records;

1084 /**
1085  This class represents a query block, aka a query specification, which is
1086  a query consisting of a SELECT keyword, followed by a table list,
1087  optionally followed by a WHERE clause, a GROUP BY, etc.
1088 */
1089 class SELECT_LEX {
1090  public:
1091  /**
1092  @note the group_by and order_by lists below will probably be added to the
1093  constructor when the parser is converted into a true bottom-up design.
1094 
1095  //SQL_I_LIST<ORDER> *group_by, SQL_I_LIST<ORDER> order_by
1096  */
1097  SELECT_LEX(MEM_ROOT *mem_root, Item *where, Item *having);
1098 
1099  Item *where_cond() const { return m_where_cond; }
1100  Item **where_cond_ref() { return &m_where_cond; }
1101  void set_where_cond(Item *cond) { m_where_cond = cond; }
1102  Item *having_cond() const { return m_having_cond; }
1103  Item **having_cond_ref() { return &m_having_cond; }
1104  void set_having_cond(Item *cond) { m_having_cond = cond; }
1105  void set_query_result(Query_result *result) { m_query_result = result; }
1106  Query_result *query_result() const { return m_query_result; }
1107  bool change_query_result(THD *thd, Query_result_interceptor *new_result,
1108  Query_result_interceptor *old_result);
1109 
1110  /// Set base options for a query block (and active options too)
1111  void set_base_options(ulonglong options_arg) {
1112  DBUG_EXECUTE_IF("no_const_tables", options_arg |= OPTION_NO_CONST_TABLES;);
1113 
1114  // Make sure we do not overwrite options by accident
1115  DBUG_ASSERT(m_base_options == 0 && m_active_options == 0);
1116  m_base_options = options_arg;
1117  m_active_options = options_arg;
1118  }
1119 
1120  /// Add base options to a query block, also update active options
1121  void add_base_options(ulonglong options) {
1122  DBUG_ASSERT(first_execution);
1123  m_base_options |= options;
1124  m_active_options |= options;
1125  }
1126 
1127  /**
1128  Remove base options from a query block.
1129  Active options are also updated, and we assume here that "extra" options
1130  cannot override removed base options.
1131  */
1132  void remove_base_options(ulonglong options) {
1133  DBUG_ASSERT(first_execution);
1134  m_base_options &= ~options;
1135  m_active_options &= ~options;
1136  }
1137 
1138  /// Make active options from base options, supplied options and environment:
1139  void make_active_options(ulonglong added_options, ulonglong removed_options);
1140 
1141  /// Adjust the active option set
1142  void add_active_options(ulonglong options) { m_active_options |= options; }
1143 
1144  /// @return the active query options
1145  ulonglong active_options() const { return m_active_options; }
1146 
1147  /**
1148  Set associated tables as read_only, ie. they cannot be inserted into,
1149  updated or deleted from during this statement.
1150  Commonly used for query blocks that are part of derived tables or
1151  views that are materialized.
1152  */
1153  void set_tables_readonly() {
1154  // Set all referenced base tables as read only.
1155  for (TABLE_LIST *tr = leaf_tables; tr != nullptr; tr = tr->next_leaf)
1156  tr->set_readonly();
1157  }
1158 
1159  /// @returns a map of all tables references in the query block
1160  table_map all_tables_map() const { return (1ULL << leaf_table_count) - 1; }
1161 
1162  void remove_derived(THD *thd, TABLE_LIST *tl);
1163  bool remove_aggregates(THD *thd, SELECT_LEX *select);
1164 
1165  SELECT_LEX_UNIT *master_unit() const { return master; }
1166  SELECT_LEX_UNIT *first_inner_unit() const { return slave; }
1167  SELECT_LEX *outer_select() const { return master->outer_select(); }
1168  SELECT_LEX *next_select() const { return next; }
1169 
1170  TABLE_LIST *find_table_by_name(const Table_ident *ident);
1171 
1172  /**
1173  @return true If STRAIGHT_JOIN applies to all tables.
1174  @return false Else.
1175  */
1176  bool is_straight_join() {
1177  bool straight_join = true;
1178  /// false for exmaple in t1 STRAIGHT_JOIN t2 JOIN t3.
1179  for (TABLE_LIST *tbl = leaf_tables->next_leaf; tbl; tbl = tbl->next_leaf)
1180  straight_join &= tbl->straight;
1181  return straight_join || (active_options() & SELECT_STRAIGHT_JOIN);
1182  }
1183 
1184  SELECT_LEX *last_select() {
1185  SELECT_LEX *mylast = this;
1186  for (; mylast->next_select(); mylast = mylast->next_select()) {
1187  }
1188  return mylast;
1189  }
1190 
1191  SELECT_LEX *next_select_in_list() const { return link_next; }
1192 
1193  void mark_as_dependent(SELECT_LEX *last, bool aggregate);
1194 
1195  /// @return true if query block is explicitly grouped (non-empty GROUP BY)
1196  bool is_explicitly_grouped() const { return group_list.elements > 0; }
1197 
1198  /**
1199  @return true if this query block is implicitly grouped, ie it is not
1200  explicitly grouped but contains references to set functions.
1201  The query will return max. 1 row (@see also is_single_grouped()).
1202  */
1203  bool is_implicitly_grouped() const {
1204  return m_agg_func_used && group_list.elements == 0;
1205  }
1206 
1207  /**
1208  True if this query block is implicitly grouped.
1209 
1210  @note Not reliable before name resolution.
1211 
1212  @return true if this query block is implicitly grouped and returns exactly
1213  one row, which happens when it does not have a HAVING clause.
1214 
1215  @remark This function is currently unused.
1216  */
1217  bool is_single_grouped() const {
1218  return m_agg_func_used && group_list.elements == 0 &&
1219  m_having_cond == nullptr;
1220  }
1221 
1222  /**
1223  @return true if this query block is explicitly or implicitly grouped.
1224  @note a query with DISTINCT is not considered to be aggregated.
1225  @note in standard SQL, a query with HAVING is defined as grouped, however
1226  MySQL allows HAVING without any aggregation to be the same as WHERE.
1227  */
1228  bool is_grouped() const { return group_list.elements > 0 || m_agg_func_used; }
1229 
1230  /// @return true if this query block contains DISTINCT at start of select list
1231  bool is_distinct() const { return active_options() & SELECT_DISTINCT; }
1232 
1233  /**
1234  @return true if this query block contains an ORDER BY clause.
1235 
1236  @note returns false if ORDER BY has been eliminated, e.g if the query
1237  can return max. 1 row.
1238  */
1239  bool is_ordered() const { return order_list.elements > 0; }
1240 
1241  /**
1242  Based on the structure of the query at resolution time, it is possible to
1243  conclude that DISTINCT is useless and remove it.
1244  This is the case if:
1245  - all GROUP BY expressions are in SELECT list, so resulting group rows are
1246  distinct,
1247  - and ROLLUP is not specified, so it adds no row for NULLs.
1248 
1249  @returns true if we can remove DISTINCT.
1250 
1251  @todo could refine this to if ROLLUP were specified and all GROUP
1252  expressions were non-nullable, because ROLLUP then adds only NULL values.
1253  Currently, ROLLUP+DISTINCT is rejected because executor cannot handle
1254  it in all cases.
1255  */
1256  bool can_skip_distinct() const {
1257  return is_grouped() && hidden_group_field_count == 0 &&
1258  olap == UNSPECIFIED_OLAP_TYPE;
1259  }
1260 
1261  /// @return true if this query block has a LIMIT clause
1262  bool has_limit() const { return select_limit != nullptr; }
1263 
1264  /// @return true if query block references full-text functions
1265  bool has_ft_funcs() const { return ftfunc_list->elements > 0; }

1801 
1802  /**
1803  All expressions needed after join and filtering, ie., select list,
1804  group by list, having clause, window clause, order by clause,
1805  including hidden fields.
1806  Does not include join conditions nor where clause.
1807 
1808  This should ideally be changed into Mem_root_array<Item *>, but
1809  find_order_in_list() depends on pointer stability (it stores a pointer
1810  to an element in referenced_by[]). Similarly, there are some instances
1811  of thd->change_item_tree() that store pointers to elements in this list.
1812 
1813  Because of this, adding or removing elements in the middle is not allowed;
1814  std::deque guarantees pointer stability only in the face of adding
1815  or removing elements from either end, ie., {push,pop}_{front_back}.
1816 
1817  Currently, all hidden items must be before all visible items.
1818  This is primarily due to the requirement for pointer stability
1819  (remove_hidden_fields() runs during cleanup), but also because
1820  change_to_use_tmp_fields() depends on it when mapping items to
1821  ref_item_array indexes. It would be good to get rid of this
1822  requirement in the future.
1823  */
1824  mem_root_deque<Item *> fields;
1825 
1826  /**
1827  All windows defined on the select, both named and inlined
1828  */
1829  List<Window> m_windows;
1830 
1831  /**
1832  Usually a pointer to ftfunc_list_alloc, but in UNION this is used to create
1833  fake select_lex that consolidates result fields of UNION
1834  */
1835  List<Item_func_match> *ftfunc_list;
1836  List<Item_func_match> ftfunc_list_alloc{};

2171  /**
2172  Transform eligible scalar subqueries in the SELECT list, WHERE condition,
2173  HAVING condition or JOIN conditions of a query block[*] to an equivalent
2174  derived table of a LEFT OUTER join, e.g. as shown in this uncorrelated
2175  subquery:
2176 
2177  [*] a.k.a "transformed query block" throughout this method and its minions.
2178 
2179  <pre>
2180  SELECT * FROM t1
2181  WHERE t1.a > (SELECT COUNT(a) AS cnt FROM t2); ->
2182 
2183  SELECT t1.* FROM t1 LEFT OUTER JOIN
2184  (SELECT COUNT(a) AS cnt FROM t2) AS derived
2185  ON TRUE WHERE t1.a > derived.cnt;
2186  </pre>
2187 
2188  Grouping in the transformed query block may necessitate the grouping to be
2189  moved down to another derived table, cf. transform_grouped_to_derived.
2190 
2191  Limitations:
2192  - only implicitly grouped subqueries (guaranteed to have cardinality one)
2193  are identified as scalar subqueries.
2194  _ Correlated subqueries are not handled
2195 
2196  @param[in,out] thd the session context
2197  @returns true on error
2198  */
2199  bool transform_scalar_subqueries_to_join_with_derived(THD *thd);
2200  bool transform_grouped_to_derived(THD *thd, bool *break_off);
2201  bool replace_subquery_in_expr(THD *thd, Item_singlerow_subselect *subquery,
2202  TABLE_LIST *tr, Item **expr);

2314 /// Utility RAII class to save/modify/restore the condition_context information
2315 /// of a query block. @see enum_condition_context.
2316 class Condition_context {
2317  public:
2318  Condition_context(SELECT_LEX *select_ptr, enum_condition_context new_type =
2319  enum_condition_context::NEITHER)
2320  : select(nullptr), saved_value() {
2321  if (select_ptr) {
2322  select = select_ptr;
2323  saved_value = select->condition_context;
2324  // More restrictive wins over less restrictive:
2325  if (new_type == enum_condition_context::NEITHER ||
2326  (new_type == enum_condition_context::ANDS_ORS &&
2327  saved_value == enum_condition_context::ANDS))
2328  select->condition_context = new_type;
2329  }
2330  }
2331  ~Condition_context() {
2332  if (select) select->condition_context = saved_value;
2333  }
2334 
2335  private:
2336  SELECT_LEX *select;
2337  enum_condition_context saved_value;
2338 };

2397 class Sroutine_hash_entry;
2398 
2399 /*
2400  Class representing list of all tables used by statement and other
2401  information which is necessary for opening and locking its tables,
2402  like SQL command for this statement.
2403 
2404  Also contains information about stored functions used by statement
2405  since during its execution we may have to add all tables used by its
2406  stored functions/triggers to this list in order to pre-open and lock
2407  them.
2408 
2409  Also used by LEX::reset_n_backup/restore_backup_query_tables_list()
2410  methods to save and restore this information.
2411 */
2412 
2413 class Query_tables_list {
2414  public:
2415  Query_tables_list &operator=(Query_tables_list &&) = default;
2416 
2417  /**
2418  SQL command for this statement. Part of this class since the
2419  process of opening and locking tables for the statement needs
2420  this information to determine correct type of lock for some of
2421  the tables.
2422  */
2423  enum_sql_command sql_command;
2424  /* Global list of all tables used by this statement */
2425  TABLE_LIST *query_tables;
2426  /* Pointer to next_global member of last element in the previous list. */
2427  TABLE_LIST **query_tables_last;
2428  /*
2429  If non-0 then indicates that query requires prelocking and points to
2430  next_global member of last own element in query table list (i.e. last
2431  table which was not added to it as part of preparation to prelocking).
2432  0 - indicates that this query does not need prelocking.
2433  */
2434  TABLE_LIST **query_tables_own_last;
2435  /*
2436  Set of stored routines called by statement.
2437  (Note that we use lazy-initialization for this hash).
2438 
2439  See Sroutine_hash_entry for explanation why this hash uses binary
2440  key comparison.
2441  */
2442  enum { START_SROUTINES_HASH_SIZE = 16 };
2443  std::unique_ptr<malloc_unordered_map<std::string, Sroutine_hash_entry *>>
2444  sroutines;
2445  /*
2446  List linking elements of 'sroutines' set. Allows you to add new elements
2447  to this set as you iterate through the list of existing elements.
2448  'sroutines_list_own_last' is pointer to ::next member of last element of
2449  this list which represents routine which is explicitly used by query.
2450  'sroutines_list_own_elements' number of explicitly used routines.
2451  We use these two members for restoring of 'sroutines_list' to the state
2452  in which it was right after query parsing.
2453  */
2454  SQL_I_List<Sroutine_hash_entry> sroutines_list;
2455  Sroutine_hash_entry **sroutines_list_own_last;
2456  uint sroutines_list_own_elements;
2457 
2458  /**
2459  Locking state of tables in this particular statement.
2460 
2461  If we under LOCK TABLES or in prelocked mode we consider tables
2462  for the statement to be "locked" if there was a call to lock_tables()
2463  (which called handler::start_stmt()) for tables of this statement
2464  and there was no matching close_thread_tables() call.
2465 
2466  As result this state may differ significantly from one represented
2467  by Open_tables_state::lock/locked_tables_mode more, which are always
2468  "on" under LOCK TABLES or in prelocked mode.
2469  */
2470  enum enum_lock_tables_state { LTS_NOT_LOCKED = 0, LTS_LOCKED };
2471  enum_lock_tables_state lock_tables_state;
2472  bool is_query_tables_locked() const {
2473  return (lock_tables_state == LTS_LOCKED);
2474  }
2475 
2476  /**
2477  Number of tables which were open by open_tables() and to be locked
2478  by lock_tables().
2479  Note that we set this member only in some cases, when this value
2480  needs to be passed from open_tables() to lock_tables() which are
2481  separated by some amount of code.
2482  */
2483  uint table_count;
2484 
2485  /*
2486  These constructor and destructor serve for creation/destruction
2487  of Query_tables_list instances which are used as backup storage.
2488  */
2489  Query_tables_list() {}
2490  ~Query_tables_list() {}
2491 
2492  /* Initializes (or resets) Query_tables_list object for "real" use. */
2493  void reset_query_tables_list(bool init);
2494  void destroy_query_tables_list();
2495  void set_query_tables_list(Query_tables_list *state) {
2496  *this = std::move(*state);
2497  }
2498 
2499  /*
2500  Direct addition to the list of query tables.
2501  If you are using this function, you must ensure that the table
2502  object, in particular table->db member, is initialized.
2503  */
2504  void add_to_query_tables(TABLE_LIST *table) {
2505  *(table->prev_global = query_tables_last) = table;
2506  query_tables_last = &table->next_global;
2507  }
2508  bool requires_prelocking() { return query_tables_own_last; }
2509  void mark_as_requiring_prelocking(TABLE_LIST **tables_own_last) {
2510  query_tables_own_last = tables_own_last;
2511  }
2512  /* Return pointer to first not-own table in query-tables or 0 */
2513  TABLE_LIST *first_not_own_table() {
2514  return (query_tables_own_last ? *query_tables_own_last : nullptr);
2515  }
2516  void chop_off_not_own_tables() {
2517  if (query_tables_own_last) {
2518  *query_tables_own_last = nullptr;
2519  query_tables_last = query_tables_own_last;
2520  query_tables_own_last = nullptr;
2521  }
2522  }
2523 
2524  /**
2525  All types of unsafe statements.
2526 
2527  @note The int values of the enum elements are used to point to
2528  bits in two bitmaps in two different places:
2529 
2530  - Query_tables_list::binlog_stmt_flags
2531  - THD::binlog_unsafe_warning_flags
2532 
2533  Hence in practice this is not an enum at all, but a map from
2534  symbols to bit indexes.
2535 
2536  The ordering of elements in this enum must correspond to the order of
2537  elements in the array binlog_stmt_unsafe_errcode.
2538  */
2539  enum enum_binlog_stmt_unsafe {
2540  /**
2541  SELECT..LIMIT is unsafe because the set of rows returned cannot
2542  be predicted.
2543  */
2544  BINLOG_STMT_UNSAFE_LIMIT = 0,
2545  /**
2546  Access to log tables is unsafe because slave and master probably
2547  log different things.
2548  */
2549  BINLOG_STMT_UNSAFE_SYSTEM_TABLE,
2550  /**
2551  Inserting into an autoincrement column in a stored routine is unsafe.
2552  Even with just one autoincrement column, if the routine is invoked more
2553  than once slave is not guaranteed to execute the statement graph same way
2554  as the master. And since it's impossible to estimate how many times a
2555  routine can be invoked at the query pre-execution phase (see lock_tables),
2556  the statement is marked pessimistically unsafe.
2557  */
2558  BINLOG_STMT_UNSAFE_AUTOINC_COLUMNS,
2559  /**
2560  Using a UDF (user-defined function) is unsafe.
2561  */
2562  BINLOG_STMT_UNSAFE_UDF,
2563  /**
2564  Using most system variables is unsafe, because slave may run
2565  with different options than master.
2566  */
2567  BINLOG_STMT_UNSAFE_SYSTEM_VARIABLE,
2568  /**
2569  Using some functions is unsafe (e.g., UUID).
2570  */
2571  BINLOG_STMT_UNSAFE_SYSTEM_FUNCTION,
2572 
2573  /**
2574  Mixing transactional and non-transactional statements are unsafe if
2575  non-transactional reads or writes are occur after transactional
2576  reads or writes inside a transaction.
2577  */
2578  BINLOG_STMT_UNSAFE_NONTRANS_AFTER_TRANS,
2579 
2580  /**
2581  Mixing self-logging and non-self-logging engines in a statement
2582  is unsafe.
2583  */
2584  BINLOG_STMT_UNSAFE_MULTIPLE_ENGINES_AND_SELF_LOGGING_ENGINE,
2585 
2586  /**
2587  Statements that read from both transactional and non-transactional
2588  tables and write to any of them are unsafe.
2589  */
2590  BINLOG_STMT_UNSAFE_MIXED_STATEMENT,
2591 
2592  /**
2593  INSERT...IGNORE SELECT is unsafe because which rows are ignored depends
2594  on the order that rows are retrieved by SELECT. This order cannot be
2595  predicted and may differ on master and the slave.
2596  */
2597  BINLOG_STMT_UNSAFE_INSERT_IGNORE_SELECT,
2598 
2599  /**
2600  INSERT...SELECT...UPDATE is unsafe because which rows are updated depends
2601  on the order that rows are retrieved by SELECT. This order cannot be
2602  predicted and may differ on master and the slave.
2603  */
2604  BINLOG_STMT_UNSAFE_INSERT_SELECT_UPDATE,
2605 
2606  /**
2607  Query that writes to a table with auto_inc column after selecting from
2608  other tables are unsafe as the order in which the rows are retrieved by
2609  select may differ on master and slave.
2610  */
2611  BINLOG_STMT_UNSAFE_WRITE_AUTOINC_SELECT,
2612 
2613  /**
2614  INSERT...REPLACE SELECT is unsafe because which rows are replaced depends
2615  on the order that rows are retrieved by SELECT. This order cannot be
2616  predicted and may differ on master and the slave.
2617  */
2618  BINLOG_STMT_UNSAFE_REPLACE_SELECT,
2619 
2620  /**
2621  CREATE TABLE... IGNORE... SELECT is unsafe because which rows are ignored
2622  depends on the order that rows are retrieved by SELECT. This order cannot
2623  be predicted and may differ on master and the slave.
2624  */
2625  BINLOG_STMT_UNSAFE_CREATE_IGNORE_SELECT,
2626 
2627  /**
2628  CREATE TABLE...REPLACE... SELECT is unsafe because which rows are replaced
2629  depends on the order that rows are retrieved from SELECT. This order
2630  cannot be predicted and may differ on master and the slave
2631  */
2632  BINLOG_STMT_UNSAFE_CREATE_REPLACE_SELECT,
2633 
2634  /**
2635  CREATE TABLE...SELECT on a table with auto-increment column is unsafe
2636  because which rows are replaced depends on the order that rows are
2637  retrieved from SELECT. This order cannot be predicted and may differ on
2638  master and the slave
2639  */
2640  BINLOG_STMT_UNSAFE_CREATE_SELECT_AUTOINC,
2641 
2642  /**
2643  UPDATE...IGNORE is unsafe because which rows are ignored depends on the
2644  order that rows are updated. This order cannot be predicted and may differ
2645  on master and the slave.
2646  */
2647  BINLOG_STMT_UNSAFE_UPDATE_IGNORE,
2648 
2649  /**
2650  INSERT... ON DUPLICATE KEY UPDATE on a table with more than one
2651  UNIQUE KEYS is unsafe.
2652  */
2653  BINLOG_STMT_UNSAFE_INSERT_TWO_KEYS,
2654 
2655  /**
2656  INSERT into auto-inc field which is not the first part in composed
2657  primary key.
2658  */
2659  BINLOG_STMT_UNSAFE_AUTOINC_NOT_FIRST,
2660 
2661  /**
2662  Using a plugin is unsafe.
2663  */
2664  BINLOG_STMT_UNSAFE_FULLTEXT_PLUGIN,
2665  BINLOG_STMT_UNSAFE_SKIP_LOCKED,
2666  BINLOG_STMT_UNSAFE_NOWAIT,
2667 
2668  /**
2669  XA transactions and statements.
2670  */
2671  BINLOG_STMT_UNSAFE_XA,
2672 
2673  /**
2674  If a substatement inserts into or updates a table that has a column with
2675  an unsafe DEFAULT expression, it may not have the same effect on the
2676  slave.
2677  */
2678  BINLOG_STMT_UNSAFE_DEFAULT_EXPRESSION_IN_SUBSTATEMENT,
2679 
2680  /**
2681  DML or DDL statement that reads a ACL table is unsafe, because the row
2682  are read without acquiring SE row locks. This would allow ACL tables to
2683  be updated by concurrent thread. It would not have the same effect on the
2684  slave.
2685  */
2686  BINLOG_STMT_UNSAFE_ACL_TABLE_READ_IN_DML_DDL,
2687 
2688  /* the last element of this enumeration type. */
2689  BINLOG_STMT_UNSAFE_COUNT
2690  };
2691  /**
2692  This has all flags from 0 (inclusive) to BINLOG_STMT_FLAG_COUNT
2693  (exclusive) set.
2694  */
2695  static const int BINLOG_STMT_UNSAFE_ALL_FLAGS =
2696  ((1 << BINLOG_STMT_UNSAFE_COUNT) - 1);
2697 
2698  /**
2699  Maps elements of enum_binlog_stmt_unsafe to error codes.
2700  */
2701  static const int binlog_stmt_unsafe_errcode[BINLOG_STMT_UNSAFE_COUNT];
2702 
2703  /**
2704  Determine if this statement is marked as unsafe.
2705 
2706  @retval 0 if the statement is not marked as unsafe.
2707  @retval nonzero if the statement is marked as unsafe.
2708  */
2709  inline bool is_stmt_unsafe() const { return get_stmt_unsafe_flags() != 0; }
2710 
2711  inline bool is_stmt_unsafe(enum_binlog_stmt_unsafe unsafe) {
2712  return binlog_stmt_flags & (1 << unsafe);
2713  }
2714 
2715  /**
2716  Flag the current (top-level) statement as unsafe.
2717  The flag will be reset after the statement has finished.
2718 
2719  @param unsafe_type The type of unsafety: one of the @c
2720  BINLOG_STMT_FLAG_UNSAFE_* flags in @c enum_binlog_stmt_flag.
2721  */
2722  inline void set_stmt_unsafe(enum_binlog_stmt_unsafe unsafe_type) {
2723  DBUG_TRACE;
2724  DBUG_ASSERT(unsafe_type >= 0 && unsafe_type < BINLOG_STMT_UNSAFE_COUNT);
2725  binlog_stmt_flags |= (1U << unsafe_type);
2726  return;
2727  }
2728 
2729  /**
2730  Set the bits of binlog_stmt_flags determining the type of
2731  unsafeness of the current statement. No existing bits will be
2732  cleared, but new bits may be set.
2733 
2734  @param flags A binary combination of zero or more bits, (1<<flag)
2735  where flag is a member of enum_binlog_stmt_unsafe.
2736  */
2737  inline void set_stmt_unsafe_flags(uint32 flags) {
2738  DBUG_TRACE;
2739  DBUG_ASSERT((flags & ~BINLOG_STMT_UNSAFE_ALL_FLAGS) == 0);
2740  binlog_stmt_flags |= flags;
2741  return;
2742  }
2743 
2744  /**
2745  Return a binary combination of all unsafe warnings for the
2746  statement. If the statement has been marked as unsafe by the
2747  'flag' member of enum_binlog_stmt_unsafe, then the return value
2748  from this function has bit (1<<flag) set to 1.
2749  */
2750  inline uint32 get_stmt_unsafe_flags() const {
2751  DBUG_TRACE;
2752  return binlog_stmt_flags & BINLOG_STMT_UNSAFE_ALL_FLAGS;
2753  }
2754 
2755  /**
2756  Determine if this statement is a row injection.
2757 
2758  @retval 0 if the statement is not a row injection
2759  @retval nonzero if the statement is a row injection
2760  */
2761  inline bool is_stmt_row_injection() const {
2762  return binlog_stmt_flags &
2763  (1U << (BINLOG_STMT_UNSAFE_COUNT + BINLOG_STMT_TYPE_ROW_INJECTION));
2764  }
2765 
2766  /**
2767  Flag the statement as a row injection. A row injection is either
2768  a BINLOG statement, or a row event in the relay log executed by
2769  the slave SQL thread.
2770  */
2771  inline void set_stmt_row_injection() {
2772  DBUG_TRACE;
2773  binlog_stmt_flags |=
2774  (1U << (BINLOG_STMT_UNSAFE_COUNT + BINLOG_STMT_TYPE_ROW_INJECTION));
2775  return;
2776  }
2777 
2778  enum enum_stmt_accessed_table {
2779  /*
2780  If a transactional table is about to be read. Note that
2781  a write implies a read.
2782  */
2783  STMT_READS_TRANS_TABLE = 0,
2784  /*
2785  If a non-transactional table is about to be read. Note that
2786  a write implies a read.
2787  */
2788  STMT_READS_NON_TRANS_TABLE,
2789  /*
2790  If a temporary transactional table is about to be read. Note
2791  that a write implies a read.
2792  */
2793  STMT_READS_TEMP_TRANS_TABLE,
2794  /*
2795  If a temporary non-transactional table is about to be read. Note
2796  that a write implies a read.
2797  */
2798  STMT_READS_TEMP_NON_TRANS_TABLE,
2799  /*
2800  If a transactional table is about to be updated.
2801  */
2802  STMT_WRITES_TRANS_TABLE,
2803  /*
2804  If a non-transactional table is about to be updated.
2805  */
2806  STMT_WRITES_NON_TRANS_TABLE,
2807  /*
2808  If a temporary transactional table is about to be updated.
2809  */
2810  STMT_WRITES_TEMP_TRANS_TABLE,
2811  /*
2812  If a temporary non-transactional table is about to be updated.
2813  */
2814  STMT_WRITES_TEMP_NON_TRANS_TABLE,
2815  /*
2816  The last element of the enumeration. Please, if necessary add
2817  anything before this.
2818  */
2819  STMT_ACCESS_TABLE_COUNT
2820  };
2821 
2822 #ifndef DBUG_OFF
2823  static inline const char *stmt_accessed_table_string(
2824  enum_stmt_accessed_table accessed_table) {
2825  switch (accessed_table) {
2826  case STMT_READS_TRANS_TABLE:
2827  return "STMT_READS_TRANS_TABLE";
2828  break;
2829  case STMT_READS_NON_TRANS_TABLE:
2830  return "STMT_READS_NON_TRANS_TABLE";
2831  break;
2832  case STMT_READS_TEMP_TRANS_TABLE:
2833  return "STMT_READS_TEMP_TRANS_TABLE";
2834  break;
2835  case STMT_READS_TEMP_NON_TRANS_TABLE:
2836  return "STMT_READS_TEMP_NON_TRANS_TABLE";
2837  break;
2838  case STMT_WRITES_TRANS_TABLE:
2839  return "STMT_WRITES_TRANS_TABLE";
2840  break;
2841  case STMT_WRITES_NON_TRANS_TABLE:
2842  return "STMT_WRITES_NON_TRANS_TABLE";
2843  break;
2844  case STMT_WRITES_TEMP_TRANS_TABLE:
2845  return "STMT_WRITES_TEMP_TRANS_TABLE";
2846  break;
2847  case STMT_WRITES_TEMP_NON_TRANS_TABLE:
2848  return "STMT_WRITES_TEMP_NON_TRANS_TABLE";
2849  break;
2850  case STMT_ACCESS_TABLE_COUNT:
2851  default:
2852  DBUG_ASSERT(0);
2853  break;
2854  }
2855  MY_ASSERT_UNREACHABLE();
2856  return "";
2857  }
2858 #endif /* DBUG */
2859 
2860 #define BINLOG_DIRECT_ON \
2861  0xF0 /* unsafe when \
2862  --binlog-direct-non-trans-updates \
2863  is ON */
2864 
2865 #define BINLOG_DIRECT_OFF \
2866  0xF /* unsafe when \
2867  --binlog-direct-non-trans-updates \
2868  is OFF */
2869 
2870 #define TRX_CACHE_EMPTY 0x33 /* unsafe when trx-cache is empty */
2871 
2872 #define TRX_CACHE_NOT_EMPTY 0xCC /* unsafe when trx-cache is not empty */
2873 
2874 #define IL_LT_REPEATABLE 0xAA /* unsafe when < ISO_REPEATABLE_READ */
2875 
2876 #define IL_GTE_REPEATABLE 0x55 /* unsafe when >= ISO_REPEATABLE_READ */
2877 
2878  /**
2879  Sets the type of table that is about to be accessed while executing a
2880  statement.
2881 
2882  @param accessed_table Enumeration type that defines the type of table,
2883  e.g. temporary, transactional, non-transactional.
2884  */
2885  inline void set_stmt_accessed_table(enum_stmt_accessed_table accessed_table) {
2886  DBUG_TRACE;
2887 
2888  DBUG_ASSERT(accessed_table >= 0 &&
2889  accessed_table < STMT_ACCESS_TABLE_COUNT);
2890  stmt_accessed_table_flag |= (1U << accessed_table);
2891 
2892  return;
2893  }
2894 
2895  /**
2896  Checks if a type of table is about to be accessed while executing a
2897  statement.
2898 
2899  @param accessed_table Enumeration type that defines the type of table,
2900  e.g. temporary, transactional, non-transactional.
2901 
2902  @retval true if the type of the table is about to be accessed
2903  @retval false otherwise
2904  */
2905  inline bool stmt_accessed_table(enum_stmt_accessed_table accessed_table) {
2906  DBUG_TRACE;
2907 
2908  DBUG_ASSERT(accessed_table >= 0 &&
2909  accessed_table < STMT_ACCESS_TABLE_COUNT);
2910 
2911  return (stmt_accessed_table_flag & (1U << accessed_table)) != 0;
2912  }
2913 
2914  /*
2915  Checks if a mixed statement is unsafe.
2916 
2917 
2918  @param in_multi_stmt_transaction_mode defines if there is an on-going
2919  multi-transactional statement.
2920  @param binlog_direct defines if --binlog-direct-non-trans-updates is
2921  active.
2922  @param trx_cache_is_not_empty defines if the trx-cache is empty or not.
2923  @param trx_isolation defines the isolation level.
2924 
2925  @return
2926  @retval true if the mixed statement is unsafe
2927  @retval false otherwise
2928  */
2929  inline bool is_mixed_stmt_unsafe(bool in_multi_stmt_transaction_mode,
2930  bool binlog_direct,
2931  bool trx_cache_is_not_empty,
2932  uint tx_isolation) {
2933  bool unsafe = false;
2934 
2935  if (in_multi_stmt_transaction_mode) {
2936  uint condition =
2937  (binlog_direct ? BINLOG_DIRECT_ON : BINLOG_DIRECT_OFF) &
2938  (trx_cache_is_not_empty ? TRX_CACHE_NOT_EMPTY : TRX_CACHE_EMPTY) &
2939  (tx_isolation >= ISO_REPEATABLE_READ ? IL_GTE_REPEATABLE
2940  : IL_LT_REPEATABLE);
2941 
2942  unsafe = (binlog_unsafe_map[stmt_accessed_table_flag] & condition);
2943 
2944 #if !defined(DBUG_OFF)
2945  DBUG_PRINT("LEX::is_mixed_stmt_unsafe",
2946  ("RESULT %02X %02X %02X\n", condition,
2947  binlog_unsafe_map[stmt_accessed_table_flag],
2948  (binlog_unsafe_map[stmt_accessed_table_flag] & condition)));
2949 
2950  int type_in = 0;
2951  for (; type_in < STMT_ACCESS_TABLE_COUNT; type_in++) {
2952  if (stmt_accessed_table((enum_stmt_accessed_table)type_in))
2953  DBUG_PRINT("LEX::is_mixed_stmt_unsafe",
2954  ("ACCESSED %s ", stmt_accessed_table_string(
2955  (enum_stmt_accessed_table)type_in)));
2956  }
2957 #endif
2958  }
2959 
2960  if (stmt_accessed_table(STMT_WRITES_NON_TRANS_TABLE) &&
2961  stmt_accessed_table(STMT_READS_TRANS_TABLE) &&
2962  tx_isolation < ISO_REPEATABLE_READ)
2963  unsafe = true;
2964  else if (stmt_accessed_table(STMT_WRITES_TEMP_NON_TRANS_TABLE) &&
2965  stmt_accessed_table(STMT_READS_TRANS_TABLE) &&
2966  tx_isolation < ISO_REPEATABLE_READ)
2967  unsafe = true;
2968 
2969  return (unsafe);
2970  }
2971 
2972  /**
2973  true if the parsed tree contains references to stored procedures
2974  or functions, false otherwise
2975  */
2976  bool uses_stored_routines() const { return sroutines_list.elements != 0; }
2977 
2978  void set_using_match() { using_match = true; }
2979  bool get_using_match() { return using_match; }
2980 
2981  void set_stmt_unsafe_with_mixed_mode() { stmt_unsafe_with_mixed_mode = true; }
2982  bool is_stmt_unsafe_with_mixed_mode() const {
2983  return stmt_unsafe_with_mixed_mode;
2984  }
2985 
2986  private:
2987  /**
2988  Enumeration listing special types of statements.
2989 
2990  Currently, the only possible type is ROW_INJECTION.
2991  */
2992  enum enum_binlog_stmt_type {
2993  /**
2994  The statement is a row injection (i.e., either a BINLOG
2995  statement or a row event executed by the slave SQL thread).
2996  */
2997  BINLOG_STMT_TYPE_ROW_INJECTION = 0,
2998 
2999  /** The last element of this enumeration type. */
3000  BINLOG_STMT_TYPE_COUNT
3001  };
3002 
3003  /**
3004  Bit field indicating the type of statement.
3005 
3006  There are two groups of bits:
3007 
3008  - The low BINLOG_STMT_UNSAFE_COUNT bits indicate the types of
3009  unsafeness that the current statement has.
3010 
3011  - The next BINLOG_STMT_TYPE_COUNT bits indicate if the statement
3012  is of some special type.
3013 
3014  This must be a member of LEX, not of THD: each stored procedure
3015  needs to remember its unsafeness state between calls and each
3016  stored procedure has its own LEX object (but no own THD object).
3017  */
3018  uint32 binlog_stmt_flags;
3019 
3020  /**
3021  Bit field that determines the type of tables that are about to be
3022  be accessed while executing a statement.
3023  */
3024  uint32 stmt_accessed_table_flag;
3025 
3026  /**
3027  It will be set true if 'MATCH () AGAINST' is used in the statement.
3028  */
3029  bool using_match;
3030 
3031  /**
3032  This flag is set to true if statement is unsafe to be binlogged in STATEMENT
3033  format, when in MIXED mode.
3034  Currently this flag is set to true if stored program used in statement has
3035  CREATE/DROP temporary table operation(s) as sub-statement(s).
3036  */
3037  bool stmt_unsafe_with_mixed_mode{false};
3038 };

3053 /**
3054  The state of the lexical parser, when parsing comments.
3055 */
3056 enum enum_comment_state {
3057  /**
3058  Not parsing comments.
3059  */
3060  NO_COMMENT,
3061 
3062  /**
3063  Parsing comments that need to be preserved.
3064  (Copy '/' '*' and '*' '/' sequences to the preprocessed buffer.)
3065  Typically, these are user comments '/' '*' ... '*' '/'.
3066  */
3067  PRESERVE_COMMENT,
3068 
3069  /**
3070  Parsing comments that need to be discarded.
3071  (Don't copy '/' '*' '!' and '*' '/' sequences to the preprocessed buffer.)
3072  Typically, these are special comments '/' '*' '!' ... '*' '/',
3073  or '/' '*' '!' 'M' 'M' 'm' 'm' 'm' ... '*' '/', where the comment
3074  markers should not be expanded.
3075  */
3076  DISCARD_COMMENT
3077 };

3079 /**
3080  This class represents the character input stream consumed during lexical
3081  analysis.
3082 
3083  In addition to consuming the input stream, this class performs some comment
3084  pre processing, by filtering out out-of-bound special text from the query
3085  input stream.
3086 
3087  Two buffers, with pointers inside each, are maintained in parallel. The
3088  'raw' buffer is the original query text, which may contain out-of-bound
3089  comments. The 'cpp' (for comments pre processor) is the pre-processed buffer
3090  that contains only the query text that should be seen once out-of-bound data
3091  is removed.
3092 */
3093 
3094 class Lex_input_stream {
3095  public:
3096  /**
3097  Constructor
3098 
3099  @param grammar_selector_token_arg See grammar_selector_token.
3100  */
3101 
3102  explicit Lex_input_stream(uint grammar_selector_token_arg)
3103  : grammar_selector_token(grammar_selector_token_arg) {}
3104 
3105  /**
3106  Object initializer. Must be called before usage.
3107 
3108  @retval false OK
3109  @retval true Error
3110  */
3111  bool init(THD *thd, const char *buff, size_t length);
3112 
3113  void reset(const char *buff, size_t length);
3114 
3115  /**
3116  Set the echo mode.
3117 
3118  When echo is true, characters parsed from the raw input stream are
3119  preserved. When false, characters parsed are silently ignored.
3120  @param echo the echo mode.
3121  */
3122  void set_echo(bool echo) { m_echo = echo; }
3123 
3124  void save_in_comment_state() {
3125  m_echo_saved = m_echo;
3126  in_comment_saved = in_comment;
3127  }
3128 
3129  void restore_in_comment_state() {
3130  m_echo = m_echo_saved;
3131  in_comment = in_comment_saved;
3132  }
3133 
3134  /**
3135  Skip binary from the input stream.
3136  @param n number of bytes to accept.
3137  */
3138  void skip_binary(int n) {
3139  DBUG_ASSERT(m_ptr + n <= m_end_of_query);
3140  if (m_echo) {
3141  memcpy(m_cpp_ptr, m_ptr, n);
3142  m_cpp_ptr += n;
3143  }
3144  m_ptr += n;
3145  }
3146 
3147  /**
3148  Get a character, and advance in the stream.
3149  @return the next character to parse.
3150  */
3151  unsigned char yyGet() {
3152  DBUG_ASSERT(m_ptr <= m_end_of_query);
3153  char c = *m_ptr++;
3154  if (m_echo) *m_cpp_ptr++ = c;
3155  return c;
3156  }
3157 
3158  /**
3159  Get the last character accepted.
3160  @return the last character accepted.
3161  */
3162  unsigned char yyGetLast() const { return m_ptr[-1]; }
3163 
3164  /**
3165  Look at the next character to parse, but do not accept it.
3166  */
3167  unsigned char yyPeek() const {
3168  DBUG_ASSERT(m_ptr <= m_end_of_query);
3169  return m_ptr[0];
3170  }
3171 
3172  /**
3173  Look ahead at some character to parse.
3174  @param n offset of the character to look up
3175  */
3176  unsigned char yyPeekn(int n) const {
3177  DBUG_ASSERT(m_ptr + n <= m_end_of_query);
3178  return m_ptr[n];
3179  }
3180 
3181  /**
3182  Cancel the effect of the last yyGet() or yySkip().
3183  Note that the echo mode should not change between calls to yyGet / yySkip
3184  and yyUnget. The caller is responsible for ensuring that.
3185  */
3186  void yyUnget() {
3187  m_ptr--;
3188  if (m_echo) m_cpp_ptr--;
3189  }
3190 
3191  /**
3192  Accept a character, by advancing the input stream.
3193  */
3194  void yySkip() {
3195  DBUG_ASSERT(m_ptr <= m_end_of_query);
3196  if (m_echo)
3197  *m_cpp_ptr++ = *m_ptr++;
3198  else
3199  m_ptr++;
3200  }
3201 
3202  /**
3203  Accept multiple characters at once.
3204  @param n the number of characters to accept.
3205  */
3206  void yySkipn(int n) {
3207  DBUG_ASSERT(m_ptr + n <= m_end_of_query);
3208  if (m_echo) {
3209  memcpy(m_cpp_ptr, m_ptr, n);
3210  m_cpp_ptr += n;
3211  }
3212  m_ptr += n;
3213  }
3214 
3215  /**
3216  Puts a character back into the stream, canceling
3217  the effect of the last yyGet() or yySkip().
3218  Note that the echo mode should not change between calls
3219  to unput, get, or skip from the stream.
3220  */
3221  char *yyUnput(char ch) {
3222  *--m_ptr = ch;
3223  if (m_echo) m_cpp_ptr--;
3224  return m_ptr;
3225  }
3226 
3227  /**
3228  Inject a character into the pre-processed stream.
3229 
3230  Note, this function is used to inject a space instead of multi-character
3231  C-comment. Thus there is no boundary checks here (basically, we replace
3232  N-chars by 1-char here).
3233  */
3234  char *cpp_inject(char ch) {
3235  *m_cpp_ptr = ch;
3236  return ++m_cpp_ptr;
3237  }
3238

3242  */
3243  bool eof() const { return (m_ptr >= m_end_of_query); }

3245  /**

3248  @return true if there are less than n characters to parse
3249  */
3250  bool eof(int n) const { return ((m_ptr + n) >= m_end_of_query); }

3301  which the -1 account for.

3346 
3347  /// Skip adding of the current token's digest since it is already added
3348  ///
3349  /// Usually we calculate a digest token by token at the top-level function
3350  /// of the lexer: MYSQLlex(). However, some complex ("hintable") tokens break
3351  /// that data flow: for example, the `SELECT /*+ HINT(t) */` is the single
3352  /// token from the main parser's point of view, and we add the "SELECT"
3353  /// keyword to the digest buffer right after the lex_one_token() call,
3354  /// but the "/*+ HINT(t) */" is a sequence of separate tokens from the hint
3355  /// parser's point of view, and we add those tokens to the digest buffer
3356  /// *inside* the lex_one_token() call. Thus, the usual data flow adds
3357  /// tokens from the "/*+ HINT(t) */" string first, and only than it appends
3358  /// the "SELECT" keyword token to that stream: "/*+ HINT(t) */ SELECT".
3359  /// This is not acceptable, since we use the digest buffer to restore
3360  /// query strings in their normalized forms, so the order of added tokens is
3361  /// important. Thus, we add tokens of "hintable" keywords to a digest buffer
3362  /// right in the hint parser and skip adding of them at the caller with the
3363  /// help of skip_digest flag.
3364  bool skip_digest;
3365 
3366  void add_digest_token(uint token, Lexer_yystype *yylval);
3367 
3368  void reduce_digest_token(uint token_left, uint token_right);
3369

3375  */

3516  The synthetic 1st token to prepend token stream with.
3517 
3518  This token value tricks parser to simulate multiple %start-ing points.
3519  Currently the grammar is aware of 4 such synthetic tokens:
3520  1. GRAMMAR_SELECTOR_PART for partitioning stuff from DD,
3521  2. GRAMMAR_SELECTOR_GCOL for generated column stuff from DD,
3522  3. GRAMMAR_SELECTOR_EXPR for generic single expressions from DD/.frm.
3523  4. GRAMMAR_SELECTOR_CTE for generic subquery expressions from CTEs.
3524  5. -1 when parsing with the main grammar (no grammar selector available).
3525 
3526  @note yylex() is expected to return the value of type int:
3527  0 is for EOF and everything else for real token numbers.
3528  Bison, in its turn, generates positive token numbers.
3529  So, the negative grammar_selector_token means "not a token".
3530  In other words, -1 is "empty value".
3531  */
3532  const int grammar_selector_token;

3561 /**
3562  The LEX object currently serves three different purposes:
3563 
3564  - It contains some universal properties of an SQL command, such as
3565  sql_command, presence of IGNORE in data change statement syntax, and list
3566  of tables (query_tables).
3567 
3568  - It contains some execution state variables, like m_exec_started
3569  (set to true when execution is started), plugins (list of plugins used
3570  by statement), insert_update_values_map (a map of objects used by certain
3571  INSERT statements), etc.
3572 
3573  - It contains a number of members that should be local to subclasses of
3574  Sql_cmd, like purge_value_list (for the PURGE command), kill_value_list
3575  (for the KILL command).
3576 
3577  The LEX object is strictly a part of class Sql_cmd, for those SQL commands
3578  that are represented by an Sql_cmd class. For the remaining SQL commands,
3579  it is a standalone object linked to the current THD.
3580 
3581  The lifecycle of a LEX object is as follows:
3582 
3583  - The LEX object is constructed either on the execution mem_root
3584  (for regular statements), on a Prepared_statement mem_root (for
3585  prepared statements), on an SP mem_root (for stored procedure instructions),
3586  or created on the current mem_root for short-lived uses.
3587 
3588  - Call lex_start() to initialize a LEX object before use.
3589  This initializes the execution state part of the object.
3590  It also calls LEX::reset() to ensure that all members are properly inited.
3591 
3592  - Parse and resolve the statement, using the LEX as a work area.
3593 
3594  - Execute an SQL command: call set_exec_started() when starting to execute
3595  (actually when starting to optimize).
3596  Typically call is_exec_started() to distinguish between preparation
3597  and optimization/execution stages of SQL command execution.
3598 
3599  - Call clear_execution() when execution is finished. This will clear all
3600  execution state associated with the SQL command, it also includes calling
3601  LEX::reset_exec_started().
3602 
3603  @todo - Create subclasses of Sql_cmd to contain data that are local
3604  to specific commands.
3605 
3606  @todo - Create a Statement context object that will hold the execution state
3607  part of struct LEX.
3608 
3609  @todo - Ensure that a LEX struct is never reused, thus making e.g
3610  LEX::reset() redundant.
3611 */
3612

3746  public:
3747  /*
3748  A stack of name resolution contexts for the query. This stack is used
3749  at parse time to set local name resolution contexts for various parts
3750  of a query. For example, in a JOIN ... ON (some_condition) clause the
3751  Items in 'some_condition' must be resolved only against the operands
3752  of the the join, and not against the whole clause. Similarly, Items in
3753  subqueries should be resolved against the subqueries (and outer queries).
3754  The stack is used in the following way: when the parser detects that
3755  all Items in some clause need a local context, it creates a new context
3756  and pushes it on the stack. All newly created Items always store the
3757  top-most context in the stack. Once the parser leaves the clause that
3758  required a local context, the parser pops the top-most context.
3759  */
3760  List<Name_resolution_context> context_stack;

3773  /**
3774  This field is used as a work field during resolving to validate
3775  the use of aggregate functions. For example in a query
3776  SELECT ... FROM ...WHERE MIN(i) == 1 GROUP BY ... HAVING MIN(i) > 2
3777  MIN(i) in the WHERE clause is not allowed since only non-aggregated data
3778  is present, whereas MIN(i) in the HAVING clause is allowed because HAVING
3779  operates on the output of a grouping operation.
3780  Each query block is assigned a nesting level. This field is a bit field
3781  that contains the value one in the position of that nesting level if
3782  aggregate functions are allowed for that query block.
3783  */
3784  nesting_map allow_sum_func;
3785  /**
3786  Windowing functions are not allowed in HAVING - in contrast to group
3787  aggregates - then we need to be stricter than allow_sum_func.
3788  One bit per query block, as allow_sum_func.
3789  */
3790  nesting_map m_deny_window_func;
3791 
3792  /// If true: during prepare, we did a subquery transformation (IN-to-EXISTS,
3793  /// SOME/ANY) that doesn't currently work for subquery to a derived table
3794  /// transformation.

3922  bool is_broken() const { return m_broken; }
3923  /**
3924  Certain permanent transformations (like in2exists), if they fail, may
3925  leave the LEX in an inconsistent state. They should call the
3926  following function, so that this LEX is not reused by another execution.
3927 
3928  @todo If lex_start () were a member function of LEX, the "broken"
3929  argument could always be "true" and thus could be removed.
3930  */
3931  void mark_broken(bool broken = true) {
3932  if (broken) {
3933  /*
3934  "OPEN <cursor>" cannot be re-prepared if the cursor uses no tables
3935  ("SELECT FROM DUAL"). Indeed in that case cursor_query is left empty
3936  in constructions of sp_instr_cpush, and thus
3937  sp_lex_instr::parse_expr() cannot re-prepare. So we mark the statement
3938  as broken only if tables are used.
3939  */
3940  if (is_metadata_used()) m_broken = true;
3941  } else
3942  m_broken = false;
3943  }

4094  /**
4095  Set the current query as uncacheable.
4096 
4097  @param curr_select Current select query block
4098  @param cause Why this query is uncacheable.
4099 
4100  @details
4101  All query blocks representing subqueries, from the current one up to
4102  the outer-most one, but excluding the main query block, are also set
4103  as uncacheable.
4104  */
4105  void set_uncacheable(SELECT_LEX *curr_select, uint8 cause) {
4106  safe_to_cache_query = false;
4107 
4108  if (m_current_select == nullptr) return;
4109  SELECT_LEX *sl;
4110  SELECT_LEX_UNIT *un;
4111  for (sl = curr_select, un = sl->master_unit(); un != unit;
4112  sl = sl->outer_select(), un = sl->master_unit()) {
4113  sl->uncacheable |= cause;
4114  un->uncacheable |= cause;
4115  }
4116  }

4136  /*
4137  Is this update command where 'WHITH CHECK OPTION' clause is important
4138 
4139  SYNOPSIS
4140  LEX::which_check_option_applicable()
4141 
4142  RETURN
4143  true have to take 'WHITH CHECK OPTION' clause into account
4144  false 'WHITH CHECK OPTION' clause do not need
4145  */
4146  inline bool which_check_option_applicable() {
4147  switch (sql_command) {
4148  case SQLCOM_UPDATE:
4149  case SQLCOM_UPDATE_MULTI:
4150  case SQLCOM_INSERT:
4151  case SQLCOM_INSERT_SELECT:
4152  case SQLCOM_REPLACE:
4153  case SQLCOM_REPLACE_SELECT:
4154  case SQLCOM_LOAD:
4155  return true;
4156  default:
4157  return false;
4158  }
4159  }

4182  /**
4183  @brief check if the statement is a single-level join
4184  @return result of the check
4185  @retval true The statement doesn't contain subqueries, unions and
4186  stored procedure calls.
4187  @retval false There are subqueries, UNIONs or stored procedure calls.
4188  */
4189  bool is_single_level_stmt() {
4190  /*
4191  This check exploits the fact that the last added to all_select_list is
4192  on its top. So select_lex (as the first added) will be at the tail
4193  of the list.
4194  */
4195  if (select_lex == all_selects_list &&
4196  (sroutines == nullptr || sroutines->empty())) {
4197  DBUG_ASSERT(!all_selects_list->next_select_in_list());
4198  return true;
4199  }
4200  return false;
4201  }

4287  if (yacc_yyss != nullptr) {
4288  my_free(yacc_yyss);
4289  yacc_yyss = nullptr;

4291  if (yacc_yyvs != nullptr) {

4295  if (yacc_yyls != nullptr) {

4297  yacc_yyls = nullptr;
4298  }
4299  m_lock_type = TL_READ_DEFAULT;
4300  m_mdl_type = MDL_SHARED_READ;

4332  /**
4333  Type of lock to be used for tables being added to the statement's
4334  table list in table_factor, table_alias_ref, single_multi and
4335  table_wild_one rules.
4336  Statements which use these rules but require lock type different
4337  from one specified by this member have to override it by using
4338  SELECT_LEX::set_lock_for_tables() method.
4339 
4340  The default value of this member is TL_READ_DEFAULT. The only two
4341  cases in which we change it are:

4514 /**
4515  Check if the given string is invalid using the system charset.
4516 
4517  @param string_val Reference to the string.
4518  @param charset_info Pointer to charset info.
4519 
4520  @return true if the string has an invalid encoding using
4521  the system charset else false.
4522 */
4523 
4524 inline bool is_invalid_string(const LEX_CSTRING &string_val,
4525  const CHARSET_INFO *charset_info) {
4526  size_t valid_len;
4527  bool len_error;
4528 
4529  if (validate_string(charset_info, string_val.str, string_val.length,
4530  &valid_len, &len_error)) {
4531  char hexbuf[7];
4532  octet2hex(
4533  hexbuf, string_val.str + valid_len,
4534  static_cast<uint>(std::min<size_t>(string_val.length - valid_len, 3)));
4535  my_error(ER_INVALID_CHARACTER_STRING, MYF(0), charset_info->csname, hexbuf);
4536  return true;
4537  }
4538  return false;
4539 }

4541 /**
4542  In debug mode, verify that we're not adding an item twice to the fields list
4543  with inconsistent hidden flags. Must be called before adding the item to
4544  fields.
4545  */
4546 inline void assert_consistent_hidden_flags(
4547  const mem_root_deque<Item *> &fields MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused)),
4548  Item *item MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused)), bool hidden MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused))) {
4549 #ifndef DBUG_OFF
4550  if (std::find(fields.begin(), fields.end(), item) != fields.end()) {
4551  // The item is already in the list, so we can't add it
4552  // with a different value for hidden.
4553  assert(item->hidden == hidden);
4554  }
4555 #endif
4556 }
